channel.title: Storing Objects to Memory
channel.description: I've seen plenty of people talk about this, and I can't find out how to do this except with the Android API. Would anyone here know how this is done and why it is so useful?

item.title: Storing Objects to Memory
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:21, topic:547862”][quote author=The Enforcer link=topic=666768.msg4459577#msg4459577 date=1416865571]

At least since C++11 the register keyword is deprecated, the compiler will do a better job at deciding. I am not sure about C11.

what’s the point of deprecating it if it was just a compiler hint in the first place?

I’m not sure, perhaps because it’s quite useless as a hint and then people would not write code with that keyword and claim that it’s superior code because it puts data in registers which might not be the reality.
[/quote]

It isn’t a useless hint, it suggests to the compiler that the variable should be allocated to registers, if possible. However it is probably deprecated now because the compiler is smart enough to assign variables to the registers without the ‘hint’[/quote]
idk man that C++ boost output from the compiler looks pretty stupid to me

Read full topic

item.title: Storing Objects to Memory
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“The Enforcer, post:19, topic:547862”][quote author=t4 link=topic=666768.msg4459285#msg4459285 date=1416677747]

At least since C++11 the register keyword is deprecated, the compiler will do a better job at deciding. I am not sure about C11.

what’s the point of deprecating it if it was just a compiler hint in the first place?
[/quote]

I’m not sure, perhaps because it’s quite useless as a hint and then people would not write code with that keyword and claim that it’s superior code because it puts data in registers which might not be the reality.[/quote]

It isn’t a useless hint, it suggests to the compiler that the variable should be allocated to registers, if possible. However it is probably deprecated now because the compiler is smart enough to assign variables to the registers without the ‘hint’

Read full topic

item.title: Storing Objects to Memory
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

i wouldn’t say it’s useless, it’s a hint though. anyone that claims the compiled code places the variables in registers doesn’t understand the concept.

Read full topic

item.title: Storing Objects to Memory
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:18, topic:547862”][quote author=The Enforcer link=topic=666768.msg4459244#msg4459244 date=1416658762]
At least since C++11 the register keyword is deprecated, the compiler will do a better job at deciding. I am not sure about C11.
[/quote]
what’s the point of deprecating it if it was just a compiler hint in the first place?[/quote]

I’m not sure, perhaps because it’s quite useless as a hint and then people would not write code with that keyword and claim that it’s superior code because it puts data in registers which might not be the reality.

Read full topic

item.title: Storing Objects to Memory
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:10, topic:547862”][quote author=t4 link=topic=666768.msg4458333#msg4458333 date=1416179839]
memory is slow, use cpu registers
[/quote]
Even if you could, would there be enough space to store it?[/quote]
Even if there was enough space and you could do it, you wouldn’t. You use the registers when you are using the values. If every program populated the registers with lots of data you would waste lots of time loading and unloading this unnecessary data into the registers.

Read full topic

item.title: Storing Objects to Memory
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:10, topic:547862”][quote author=t4 link=topic=666768.msg4458333#msg4458333 date=1416179839]
memory is slow, use cpu registers
[/quote]
Even if you could, would there be enough space to store it?[/quote]
That depends entirely on the ISA and the size of what you want to store

[quote=“Rodgerwilco, post:13, topic:547862”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=666768.msg4458437#msg4458437 date=1416240928]
I like how when people can’t tell t4 is trolling.
[/quote]

His IQ too low.[/quote]
My idiocy quotient is low, yes.

Read full topic

item.title: Storing Objects to Memory
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

t4:

memory is slow, use cpu registers

This is irrelevant in this context; JIT determines which variables are in registers and the CPU determines which objects are in which cache. We don’t have control over this like we do in C

Read full topic

item.title: Storing Objects to Memory
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

Storing something in memory has the benefit of having insanely fast lookup speeds, versus having to read it from lets say a file on the hard drive every time it is needed. In Java, everything is created and stored in memory until it can no longer be reached by a reference. Of course there are still a few exceptions where the GC won’t clean it up even after it should.

Give us an example of what you’re trying to do and we can help more with showing you how

Read full topic

I’m not too sure what you mean. Any variable you declare is automatically stored in memory in Java.
